awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: Accuracy and the Regulatory Reprogramming of Bacterial Chemosensing
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).  In this project, funded by the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate and housed in the Chemistry Division, Professor Colin Kinz-Thompson and his students at Rutgers University Newark will study the bacterial chemosensory array (CA), an important process in regulatory signal transduction pathways.  Prof. Kinz-Thompson will develop a combination of advanced spectroscopy and microscopy techniques and sophisticated computational modeling approaches to help understand the molecular basis of accurate bacterial chemosensing.  In addition, Prof. Kinz-Thompson will implement a plan to help broaden participation in STEM fields by students underrepresented in the sciences, including involving underrepresented minority (URM) undergraduate students in the planned research, developing new courses to bring computational and biophysical techniques to a diverse group of students, and starting a maker lab that will participate in STEM-related outreach to local URM school children.

Professor Kinz-Thompson will develop a single-molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer assay (smFRET) to use along with free energy perturbation (FEP) calculations to quantify the energetics of substrate specificity for a bacterial chemoreceptor and the mechanism of anti-cooperativity between the ligand binding sites of that chemoreceptor.  Similar smFRET experiments will also be used, along with stochastic chemical master equation simulations, to evaluate the effectiveness of a chemosensory proofreading mechanism involving periplasmic binding proteins.  In a final scientific aim, Prof. Kinz-Thompson will use fluorescence super-resolution microscopy and Bayesian inference-based modeling to quantify the in vivo quaternary structure of the bacterial chemosensory array and the subsequent effect of a regulatory response that remodels it.  Along with enabling direct participation of undergraduate students in research activities, efforts to teach skillsets such as programing, electronics, 3D printing, and other exciting techniques outside of traditional chemistry curricula will enable future interdisciplinary scientific exchanges and encourage more students to pursue careers in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was comprised of both research and educational aims that were designed to advance the development of a cutting-edge research program at Rutgers Newark in the field of biophysical chemistry. The research aims of the project focused on investigating the molecular details of the biochemical system that allows bacteria to sense their local environment and react accordingly. That process is driven by a large assembly of proteins known as the chemosensory array (CA), which can identify small molecules in the bacteria's environment.

Over the course of this award, we developed advanced microscopy experiments to measure how the CA can accurately distinguish between different molecules. To perform these experiments, we worked to develop a new high-throughput fluorescence microscope capable of imaging individual molecules, software to analyze how the individual molecules move, and analysis algorithms to create models of the CA directly from the microscope images. With this approach, we studied changes to the structure of the CA caused by the presence of antibiotics and different ions, and how these changes regulated the ability of the CA to sense small molecules. The dynamic nature of those responses led us to interpret the CA as a "molecular machine" that is capable of being reprogrammed to respond to different situations according to the needs of the cell.

Complementing the research aims of this project, one of the educational aims involved increasing undergraduate student participation in advanced scientific research, and a total of six undergraduates received comprehensive one-on-one training in biophysical chemistry research through this project. Another educational activity was to broaden the scientific education of those entering the national workforce by creating new experiments for the undergraduate physical chemistry laboratory course at Rutgers Newark to teach the interdisciplinary skillsets involved in making scientific instruments, such as programming, electronics, and 3D printing. Continued instrumentation design projects following these laboratory experiments taught these skillsets in more depth. Additionally, a new course in biophysical chemistry was developed and taught to the graduate students in the chemistry department. This course provided interdisciplinary training in the overlap between biology, chemistry, and physics to scientists in training who will soon enter the national workforce. Altogether, the research and educational activities supported by this award have advanced the development of a highly interdisciplinary research group and expanded the scope of the larger scientific community at Rutgers Newark and more broadly in the United States.
